多布斯让堕胎权的支持者兴奋不已

新禁令使得终止合同的情况更加罕见，但民主党团结一致

北半球的盛夏是南极洲最深的冬天。非洲大陆的大部分地区都处于持续的黑暗之中，经常受到时速超过 100 英里/小时的风和低于 -60°C 的气温的破坏。它通常被广阔的、不断增长的海冰包围，通常在九月左右达到最大程度。但根据卫星数据，南极洲目前的冰量极少，是六月以来的最低水平（见图表）。这对世界其他地区意味着什么？

6月12日，非洲大陆的海冰覆盖面积仅为1070万平方公里。这比 2019 年该日期的最低记录低 115 万平方公里，比 1981-2010 年的平均水平低 230 万平方公里。第一个差异代表面积比哥伦比亚稍大；第二个区域面积有蒙古那么大——加上三个英国。

尽管有波动，但随着大气中温室气体的增加和地球变暖，地球另一端北极的海冰总体上一直在稳步下降。自 1979 年以来，其夏季表面积每十年约减少 12.6%；全球平均气温比工业化前水平高出1.0-1.3°C ，其中大部分变暖发生在 1975 年以来。尽管那里的平均气温也有所上升，但南极洲的情况却截然不同。 1979 年至 2014 年间，其年度海冰范围（被冰覆盖的海洋面积）总体略有增加。然后迅速下降，从2014年的历史高点跌至2017年的历史低点。该记录随后于2022年被打破，并于2023年2月再次被打破。今年又出现了两次历史低点。

目前尚不清楚为什么南极洲海冰最近急剧下降，也不清楚为什么在此之前有所上升。 （气候模型大多预测它的表现会更像北极：但事实并非如此，有时被称为“南极悖论”。）对于突然减少，人们提出了各种理论，包括环绕大陆的风强度的变化和更温暖的海洋。科学家们对近年来急剧下降的趋势感到不安，呼吁对气候变化到底如何影响南极洲进行更多研究。他们也越来越担心后果。海冰有助于保护大陆陆地边缘的冰架。随着气温升高，冰架已经更频繁地分裂，暴露出其后面巨大的冰盖。它们的恶化可能会带来灾难性的后果：仅西韦茨冰川所含的水就足以使全球海平面上升约 65 厘米。是什么让南极变得更加不稳定——从而变得脆弱——都值得担忧。 ■

; Mon, 26 Jun 2023 20:27:40 GMT /内容/t058pus9bj5attofqo9nhglm4ok2ruph https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2023/06/26/antarctic-sea-ice-has-shrunk-by-an-area-nine-times-the-size-of-britain Mikhail Khodorkovsky on the stark lessons from Russia’s wild weekend

叶夫根尼·普里戈任的未遂政变尽管失败了，但对俄罗斯来说却是一个地震时刻，暴露了弗拉基米尔·普京总统的脆弱性。随着兵变的展开，我建议俄罗斯的民主反战反对派应该欢迎它所提供的机会，并不是因为普里戈任先生是我们的朋友或盟友——他决不是暴徒和战犯——而是因为普京先生的倒台只能是用武力造成的。

这只是普京第二次面临真正的革命时刻，第一次是 2011-13 年的大规模抗议活动。然而当时，民主反对派无法利用这一点。我们需要清醒地认识到这样一个事实：普京政权的垮台和创建一个更好的俄罗斯不会通过投票箱或其他和平手段实现，而是需要武装起义。我们要么为此做好准备，要么袖手旁观，最终被它压垮。

只有武装民众才能推翻这个独裁政权。未遂政变的性质并非完全不可预测。事实上，我之前曾强调过普京先生面临的风险，即俄罗斯境内出现了数千名愤愤不平的人，由于他对乌克兰的犯罪入侵，这些人现在拥有武器、接受过训练并拥有使用武器的经验。我认为，如果乌克兰军队渗透到前线，一大群撤退到俄罗斯的战士就会对政权构成威胁，就像第一次世界大战中从前线撤军加速了布尔什维克的接管一样。

如果普里戈任先生成功了，认为他的政变会带来民主化、释放政治犯以及呼吁自由公正的选举，那就是异想天开。如果我们民主反对派希望实现这些目标，那么我们不仅必须支持推翻政权，而且要准备好在政权垮台时通过武力维护我们的民主利益。我们现阶段的自由不会通过准备选举来赢得。

然而，政变企图表明，普京是一只跛脚鸭，他的日子已经屈指可数了。在俄罗斯精英和整个社会看来，这对其政权的合法性造成了潜在的致命打击。他被暴露为一个软弱的领导人，无法控制自己的核心圈子和安全部队，并在受到威胁时陷入孤立。他远非是他手下内部分歧的主要操纵者，而是冒着被他释放但不再控制的力量推翻的风险。

对于普通民众来说，普里戈任的雇佣军轻而易举地占领了俄罗斯南部城市顿河畔罗斯托夫，该城市是俄罗斯军队在乌克兰的重要后勤中转站，这让人们不再相信普京享有压倒性的优势。公众支持。与此同时，俄罗斯精英不能再将他视为其地位、稳定和繁荣的保证人。

总统无法再控制他的军队，人们也不再相信他兜售的关于他不必要的罪恶战争的神话。普里戈任先生了解普京的弱点、他的战争机器的危险状态以及他的军队的士气低落。如果他认为自己没有很大的成功机会，他就不会叛变。

我们看到了该政权不可避免的垮台可能会如何发生，以及将寻求接管的势力——由另一名暴徒领导的所谓“民族爱国者”。民主反战反对派和我们在西方的天然盟友需要为该政权的垮台做好准备，不能温顺地允许目前掌管俄罗斯核武库的强盗被另一个强盗取代。

西方应该对俄罗斯的民主反对派下大注，并赋予其代理权，这样当该政权崩溃时，我们就有能力抓住时机。西方列强应该承认我们的反对派机构，例如俄罗斯行动委员会，作为俄罗斯社会的合法代表，使我们能够更好地与普里戈任模式中的军事化“民族爱国者”竞争。

与此同时，西方对乌克兰的支持决不能放松。它必须继续武装乌克兰人，推动他们走向胜利。普京的军队陷入混乱，乌克兰必须得到全力支持才能占据优势。

然而，在俄罗斯国内，现在是时候认识到普京在战争中的失败已经导致他的垮台不可避免。如果西方希望看到俄罗斯能够成为世界上负责任的行为者，那么它就需要支持民主的反战反对派。与此同时，俄罗斯反对派需要为接下来发生的事情和残酷的现实做好准备，即下一次俄罗斯革命将不会是天鹅绒革命。政权和推翻它的力量将会武装起来。我们可能憎恨普里戈任先生，但我们不能忽视他已经证明了成功破坏普京邪恶政权的潜力。

政权更迭即将到来。具体什么时候无法说。但有一件事是肯定的：我们必须为此做好准备。 ■

米哈伊尔·霍多尔科夫斯基曾是一名政治犯，也是俄罗斯尤科斯石油公司的首席执行官。他是《俄罗斯难题：西方如何陷入普京权力策略——以及如何解决》（2022 年）一书的作者。

; Mon, 26 Jun 2023 20:12:10 GMT /内容/vknb356qigq5q36m3tvk9ce1pnfmleul https://www.economist.com/by-invitation/2023/06/26/mikhail-khodorkovsky-on-the-stark-lessons-from-Russias-wild-weekend Alexander Lukashenko is the clearest beneficiary of Wagner’s mutiny

自白俄罗斯诡计多端的独裁者亚历山大·卢卡申科在俄罗斯享有如此良好的舆论以来，已有二十多年了。整个周末，克里姆林宫的宣传人员都称赞他在莫斯科门口制止叛乱分子叶夫根尼·普里戈任方面所发挥的作用。克里姆林宫拉拉队长弗拉基米尔·索洛维约夫 (Vladimir Solovyov) 兴奋地说，这位留着小胡子的领导人理应获得“俄罗斯英雄”的荣誉。 “怎么高估他的智慧和谈判才能都不过分；他表现出了最高级别的队长气质。”白俄罗斯官方媒体更是将其渲染得更加强烈。 “伊万·苏珊宁、库兹马·米宁、波扎尔斯基王子、朱可夫元帅和亚历山大·卢卡申科：这是拯救莫斯科的人的名单。”

除了乌克兰之外，亚历山大·卢卡申科是普里戈任先生及其瓦格纳集团雇佣兵短暂叛变的最大公开受益者。弗拉基米尔·普京(Vladimir Putin)在选举中失利后，承诺提供警方支持，使他免遭民众起义，三年来，这位白俄罗斯领导人在一个日益占主导地位的邻国面前扮演了次要角色。自入侵开始以来，他已14次拜访普京；普京只回过一次恩。与此同时，白俄罗斯的主权不断受到侵蚀——俄罗斯对乌克兰的入侵部分是从白俄罗斯领土发起的。然而，通过帮助俄罗斯总统和他被定罪的前厨师兼同事达成一项协议，卢卡申科已经重新振作起来。 “他夺回了自己的机构，”智库查塔姆研究所项目主任赖霍尔·阿斯塔佩尼亚 (Ryhor Astapenia) 说。

克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫(Dmitry Peskov)在宣布这项协议时表示，普里戈任和卢卡申科已签署了一份20年期债券。事实上，他们的主要联系似乎是白俄罗斯领导人 2002 年在圣彼得堡普里戈任先生的一家餐厅吃的一顿饭。“他非常喜欢这顿午餐，并与普里戈任先生握手。”在场的政治舆论专家亚历山大·齐莫夫斯基 (Alexander Zimovsky) 说道。吃饭时，“但很难说他们从那以后一直保持着认真的联系。”

白俄罗斯领导人在谈判中的作用可能同样被夸大了。一位不愿透露姓名的乌克兰高级官员表示，卢卡申科直到 6 月 24 日晚（即叛变结束前不久）才参加会谈。 “他被告知要成为中间人，他就加入了进来。”大部分谈判是由俄罗斯对话者完成的，其中包括图拉地区州长、弗拉基米尔·普京的前保镖阿列克谢·久明。据传与普里戈任关系密切的久明先生在整个事件中一直避免媒体发表评论。无论出于何种原因，克里姆林宫更希望卢卡申科为这笔交易承担功劳和责任。

该协议的细节仍然有很多未知之处。从广义上讲，普里戈任先生被承诺安全前往白俄罗斯并获得大赦，以换取调转其装甲纵队。但除此之外，混乱依然存在。一些报道称，对普里戈任先生的指控仍然成立。普里戈任先生在白俄罗斯会孤身一人，还是会与武装分子一起加入？他会被允许以任何形式公开露面吗？他能保留多少在非洲利润丰厚的雇佣军生意？白俄罗斯本身是一个封闭的政治盒子，几乎没有任何线索。 “也许已经有十几个人被告知了，仅此而已，”阿斯塔佩尼亚先生说。普京在 6 月 26 日的简短讲话中确认，如果瓦格纳战士愿意，也将被允许前往白俄罗斯，但他没有透露更多细节。

接下来发生的事情同样晦涩难懂。目前甚至不清楚普里戈任先生现在在哪里，尽管一份报告称有人在明斯克的一家酒店看到了他。很难想象普里戈任先生会在白俄罗斯担任任何重要的政治角色，更不用说军事角色了。权力的垄断程度甚至比邻国俄罗斯还要严重。如果克里姆林宫分裂并统治，卢卡申科就会扁平化。 “卢卡申科对国内安全问题过于敏感，不能给予叛变分子太多权力，”政治分析家阿尔乔姆·什莱布曼 (Artyom Shraibman) 说。 “也许他准备容忍普里戈任和他的保镖一段时间，但不会永远。”

白俄罗斯法律似乎也排除了瓦格纳雇佣军在俄罗斯境内享有的那种特权。只有公认的国家机构、军队、警察和克格勃（当地安全部门仍为人所知）的人员才有权携带武器。一种情况是普里戈任先生和他手无寸铁的手下在明斯克短暂定居，然后前往非洲集中精力开展业务。

但这并没有阻止乌克兰一些人对其他结果感到担忧。克里姆林宫建议将多达2万名瓦格纳的战士纳入俄罗斯军队。这可能会发生，也可能不会发生。至少，进军莫斯科的瓦格纳3000-5000名核心成员肯定会面临更多的战斗。乌克兰情报人士称，其中许多人是在俄罗斯精英军事学校接受过培训的经验丰富的专业人士。如果条件合适，他们仍然可以部署从白俄罗斯到乌克兰的牵制袭击：“我们不说这种情况会发生，但我们正在仔细观察。”一份报告显示，在乌克兰附近建造几个新军营的工作已经开始。其他人则否认了这种可能性，指出白俄罗斯独裁者一直小心翼翼地避免直接卷入战争。 “乌克兰拥有可以反击的武器，卢卡申科也知道这一点，”施莱布曼表示。

在乌克兰和西方，卢卡申科普遍被视为弗拉基米尔·普京入侵的共同参战者。白俄罗斯境内的情况则更为微妙。什莱布曼表示，当地人指出，他在巩固自己的体系的同时成功地避免了动员和抗议。在战争期间，他的受欢迎程度实际上有所增加，因为他在很大程度上将白俄罗斯人排除在外。白俄罗斯反对派无疑希望俄罗斯的混乱能够从普京手中转移到卢卡申科身上。但是，施莱布曼先生表示，“他已经证明不会出现多米诺骨牌效应。” ■

; Mon, 26 Jun 2023 19:53:13 GMT /内容/4ur6mkvt0q9idbal5m80lskd597ma7hr https://www.economist.com/europe/2023/06/26/alexander-lukashenko-is-the-clearest-beneficiary-of-wagners-mutiny Americans love American stocks. They should look overseas

“我知道分配模型并没有这么说，”财政部长转型为私募股权投资者的史蒂文·姆努钦 (Steven Mnuchin) 上个月承认，“但如果我必须在未来十年投入资金，我会投入 100%美国经济中的这种情况。”尽管姆努钦的爱国主义可能部分是出于意识形态——因为他既是投资者又是政治人物——但他并不孤单。数据公司Morningstar Direct的数据显示，美国基金投资者仅持有海外股票配置的六分之一。指数基金的发明人杰克·博格尔 (Jack Bogle) 称国际风险过于复杂化。投资者沃伦·巴菲特认为，在他去世后，他的妻子应该将其财富的 90% 分配给美国领先指数标准普尔500指数，将 10% 分配给美国国债。

这种爱国主义是一种奇怪的现象。毕竟，姆努钦先生是对的：这并不是资产配置模型所暗示的那样。多元化也许是现代金融中最重要的理念。它的威力由 20 世纪 50 年代 6 月 22 日去世的经济学家哈里·马科维茨（Harry Markowitz）展现出来，当时投资组合理论建议投资于未来股息现值最高的股票。马科维茨意识到这种分析忽略了风险。安迪的苹果农场平均每年回报率为 10%，但波动剧烈。鞋匠巴里 (Barry) 的年增长率稳定在 7%。只要两家公司的命运不同步，包含少量安迪和少量巴里的投资组合将比持有任一公司股票提供更好的风险调整回报。

这一见解为马科维茨赢得了诺贝尔奖。它还为博格尔的指数基金（持有大量公司的股票，而不仅仅是少数公司）和现代学术金融奠定了基础。另一位经济学家威廉·夏普发明的资本资产定价模型假设所有投资者的行为都像马科维茨所描述的那样——最大化风险调整后的回报——就像公司理论假设公司利润最大化一样。多元化对投资组合构建的各个层面都有好处。在股票方面，投资许多公司比持有少数公司要好；跨资产，持有股票、债券、房地产、大宗商品等都比持有一两项资产要好。在许多国家持有这些资产比只在一个国家持有要好。

美国人热爱美国，但没有什么比赚钱更美国化了。那么，为什么会有本土偏见呢？也许持有外国股票对于地域多元化来说并不是必要的。美国公司是跨国公司。全球范围内的增长往往是同步的。有些风险是回报波动（马科维茨的衡量标准）无法捕捉到的。没有投资组合经理会因为购买美国股票而被解雇。如果他们投资于一个没收他们资产的国家，他们就会被扫地出门。

然而爱国主义的真正原因可能更简单：它已经奏效了。三十年来，美国股市的表现一直优于世界其他地区——这是一段非常长的时间。自 1990 年以来，美国的平均每年回报率比富裕国家股票的广泛指数高出 4.6 个百分点，这是一个非常大的溢价。尽管世界各地的股市都朝着同一个方向波动，这抵消了多元化的好处，但美国的走势更快。结果是，尽管美国经济只占全球的25%，但其股票却占全球市值的60%。过去十年，这一比例上升了 12 个百分点。唯一一个份额增长超过一个百分点的国家是中国。

连胜还会继续吗？美国比其他任何地方都拥有更深入的资本市场、更强大的机构和更大的经济。创新自由流动——看看最近人工智能的繁荣就知道了。然而这些特征并不新鲜，这意味着它们应该被定价。

Cliff Asness 及其同事在aqr Capital Management 发表的一篇新论文提出了另一个警告。他们根据估值的变化调整回报，发现美国股市的优异表现绝大多数是因为估值飙升。美国股票溢价 4.6%，其中 3.4% 的溢价是因为美国的市盈率较高。只有 1.2% 来自基本面，比如更高的收益。

强劲的基本面带来的优异表现可能会重复出现。正如阿斯内斯所写，“仅仅因为人们愿意为同样的基本要素付出更多”而获胜可能并非如此。在长期连续下跌后转向外国股票可能会让人感觉有风险。但多元化的理由正在重新显现。美国是勇敢者的家园。该国的投资者应该记住这一点，并将目光投向海外。 ■

; Mon, 26 Jun 2023 19:09:21 GMT /内容/kvn8airqlpm9v42t2njk5c8a9s1ei97c https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/26/americans-love-american-stocks-they-should-look-overseas Why short prison sentences in England and Wales are a disaster

利亚姆在一家商店鲁莽地打开一罐啤酒并痛饮之后，在监狱里度过了三个星期，他和纳税人为此付出的代价远远超过了他未支付的 1.90 英镑（2.40 美元）。当他受到心理健康问题和失败的人际关系困扰时，他偷了它。入狱让他的生活变得更加糟糕。当他再次出现时，发现自己被赶出了公寓，因此不得不离开他所依赖的亲戚和朋友。他缺乏现金，因为为低收入者提供的普遍信贷福利在服刑期间被停止（新申请需要一个月才能生效）。这一切，让他感到越来越绝望。他又偷了少量酒。这次，因为他处于缓刑期，所以他得到了七周的时间。不到一年的时间里，他四次入狱。

英格兰和威尔士广泛采用短期监禁来惩罚轻罪惯犯。每年被判入狱的人中有超过一半的刑期少于 12 个月，其中大多数刑期不足 6 个月。然而，在衡量刑事司法系统的几乎所有指标上，短刑都失败了。慈善机构“旋转门”首席执行官帕万·达利瓦尔 (Pavan Dhaliwal) 表示，这是“代价高昂的政策失败”。

首先，也是最令人担忧的是，它们增加了犯罪率。超过 60% 被判处六个月以下徒刑的人在释放后一年内再次犯罪。直接比较是困难的，但对于那些被判社区刑的人（主要包括无偿工作），比率要低得多。这可能是因为犯罪率较低的罪犯更有可能被判社区刑。但司法部的一项研究表明，考虑到这种差异，社区刑罚效果更好。

短期刑罚也会失败，因为它们会让监狱变得更加混乱。太多的地方过度拥挤、充满暴力，男性（其中 96% 被关押）几乎没有工作、锻炼或学习的机会。资金不足是一个原因，但另一个原因则显得相形见绌：监狱人口规模的大幅增加。尽管自 20 世纪 90 年代以来犯罪率大幅下降，但对严重犯罪判处较长刑期意味着被监禁人数翻了一番，从约 40,000 人增加到 85,000 人（见图表）。英格兰和威尔士的滞留人口比西欧任何国家都多：每 10 万人中有 159 人滞留。欧盟平均水平为 109。这种增长看起来将持续下去。司法部预计，到 2026 年，监狱人口将达到 98,500 人。但资源、牢房或狱警的数量并未相应增加。

尽管如此，监狱还是提供了一些康复的希望。短句子搞乱了这一点。在任何时期的监狱服刑人员中，短期服刑者只是一小部分人，或许不到总数的 5%。但它们会造成不成比例的麻烦。他们进出监狱会造成混乱，使长期囚犯感到不安。屡犯轻罪的性质加剧了这种情况。囚犯通常有一些共同特征，这些特征既表明了国家的失败，也表明了罪犯道德的失败。大约四分之一的人在照顾中度过了一些童年时光。他们比大多数人更有可能出现学习障碍、文盲，并且患精神疾病的比例也更高。

然而，霍华德刑法改革联盟的安德鲁·尼尔森表示，低级别的惯犯是“系统中最混乱的人”。将他们与那些犯下更严重罪行但过着更稳定生活的人放在一起是没有帮助的。前监狱长兼监狱改革信托基金首席执行官皮亚·辛哈 (Pia Sinha) 表示：“当你在短时间内将易受伤害的人（通常患有毒瘾和心理健康问题）带入监狱时，它会耗尽系统的所有能量。” “你正在引入混乱。”她说，刑期短是监狱人员流动率高的主要原因。它们也是毒品进入监狱的主要途径。

对于囚犯本身来说，短期刑期除了让不快乐的生活变得更糟之外，没有什么作用。当囚犯被关押时，它们保护公众免受滋扰者的侵害，但没有解决导致他们行为的任何问题。 “监狱会毁掉你外面的生活，如果你把某人送出监狱几个月，就没有足够的时间让他们改过自新，”克里斯·阿特金斯（Chris Atkins）说，他是一本关于累犯的书《一次又一次》的作者。他在HMP Wandsworth 监狱度过了九个月（因税务欺诈而被判刑的一部分），在那里他多次看到其他囚犯离开和返回。

对于女性来说，这种伤害尤其严重。大多数女囚犯都犯过诸如入店行窃之类的轻微罪行。许多人都是母亲。当男人入狱时，他们的孩子通常仍住在家里。但当妇女被关押时，她们的孩子通常会被送去照顾或与亲戚住在一起。每年约有 17,000 名儿童受到影响。反过来，他们更有可能最终进入刑事司法系统。

短刑也不是伸张正义的廉价方式。把人关起来比社区选择要贵得多。每名囚犯入狱一年，国家要花费 47,000 英镑：比一所昂贵的寄宿学校还要多。社区监禁的费用只是其中的一小部分。与此同时，民意调查显示，选民并不像普遍认为的那样热衷于因盗窃等犯罪而被判入狱。

尽管如此，有些人认为短句子至关重要。智库 Civitas 在 2019 年发布的一份报告中表示，当时的监狱部长提议引入反对短刑的推定，这意味着“大多数多产的罪犯......[将]继续自由地伤害他们的邻居。”然而历届政府都同意短期刑罚不起作用。量刑指南早已明确规定，只有在没有合适的选择的情况下才应入狱。

问题在于，许多负责轻罪量刑的治安法官并不赞成主要的选择——社区判决。在缓刑部门的监督下，近年来此类刑罚的使用似乎有所减少。由于数据不完整，其原因尚不完全清楚（被判处短期徒刑的罪犯数量也有所下降）。部分原因可能是盗窃等容易导致社区监禁的犯罪行为有所减少。

一些人认为治安法官需要接受更多有关不同类型惩罚的培训。辛哈女士希望看到更多地使用判决前报告（ PSR ）。这些由缓刑服务机构制作，列出了罪犯行为的可能原因及其构成的风险，以及量刑建议。他们可以鼓励更多的治安法官将低级罪犯从监狱中转移出去。但它们需要时间。为了加快判刑，它们的使用已经减少。

社区判决常常失败。啤酒偷窃者利亚姆在 30 多岁第一次入狱之前，被分给了四颗，第一次是在他 17 岁时。法庭通常会审理已被定罪数十次的罪犯入狱。五月，缓刑首席督察贾斯汀·拉塞尔 (Justin Russell) 告诉议会，社区刑罚无法帮助那些毫无意义地被送进监狱的人。 “通常情况下，经常在商店行窃或犯下轻微罪行的街头海洛因吸食者不会获得社区命令；他们将被处以罚款或短期监禁，”拉塞尔表示，并称这是“市场缺口”。这是一件大事，因为一半的盗窃案都是由吸毒成瘾者所为。

最有效的解决方案来自对健康和福利以及正义的思考。利亚姆在第四次入狱后不再犯罪，当时他被转介到由国家医疗服务体系 ( NHS ) 和司法部运营的联络和转移服务机构。它可以识别出有心理健康问题以及吸毒和酗酒问题的罪犯。它将他介绍给一个摆脱了长期与刑事司法系统纠缠的人，并给了他实际的帮助，包括住房方面的帮助。他说，当他第一次被捕时，他感觉到警方知道他陷入了困境，但不知道该怎么办。

另一项举措是“社区判刑治疗要求协议”，该协议要求对患有精神健康问题和吸毒成瘾的罪犯进行治疗，由NHS和司法部于 2018 年发起。该举措正在英格兰各地推广：治安法官需要了解它。另一个解决方案是为一些吸毒成瘾的罪犯提供住宅戒毒所。这比监禁他们更好，从长远来看也更便宜。

然而，此类替代方案的成功还取决于运作良好的缓刑服务，而英格兰和威尔士目前还没有这种服务。很大程度上是因为 2014 年的部分私有化造成了灾难性的后果，以至于 2021 年又被逆转，缓刑服务机构正因经验丰富的员工严重短缺而苦苦挣扎。拉塞尔表示，自该服务重新国有化以来，在检查的 23 个当地缓刑区中，有 13 个“不足”。

缓刑服务机构的失败是很严重的。它们影响政客如何谈论犯罪和量刑。一月份，有消息称，过度劳累的缓刑官员将高风险罪犯列为“中等风险”；他继续性侵犯并谋杀了伦敦的一名年轻女子扎拉·阿莉娜。此类事件使得政客们不太愿意推行可能被视为对犯罪采取软弱态度的政策，即使这些政策是明智的。

工党领袖、前检察长凯尔·斯塔默爵士尤其害怕被贴上这样的标签。然而，监狱工作人员希望工党能够兑现一项宣言承诺，建立一个“创伤知情”的刑事司法系统——也就是说，承认犯罪根源往往在于童年和贫困。这种方法是唯一可能有效的方法。下一届政府采纳它是明智的。 ■

; Mon, 26 Jun 2023 17:54:54 GMT /内容/ms9mq6e3nce98tajq7cr375uup9bvplg https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/06/26/the-trouble-with-sticky-inflation-how-to-build-ukraine-20-and-the-new-king-of-beers An acrimonious debate about covid’s origins will rumble on

covid -19从哪里来？ You might imagine that the question would be a matter for science. Instead it has become embroiled in acrimony, politics and, at times, conspiracy theory.

New diseases in people almost always come from close contact between human populations and animals. A “spillover” happens when viruses from an animal species jump into humans and then go on to wreak havoc. But the idea that SARS-CoV-2 , the virus that causes covid-19, instead leaked from a Chinese research laboratory has persisted since the earliest days of the pandemic. Though this theory has rested largely on rumours and circumstantial evidence, it has nevertheless set the stage for a bitter three-and-a-half year row.

It had been hoped that information from America's intelligence services could resolve the row in favour of one theory or another. Those hopes were scotched late on June 23rd, when a report was delivered by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence ( ODNI )—as directed by Congress—on the potential links between the Wuhan Institute of Virology ( WIV ) and the origin of the pandemic. It contained no evidence of a laboratory leak. However, anyone hoping the report would burnish instead the hypothesis that covid-19 emerged in a food market in Wuhan would also have been disappointed. The report concluded that “both a natural and laboratory-associated origin remain plausible”.

Some 72% of new human infectious diseases originate in wildlife. Those include Ebola, Zika, HIV , and the original SARS (whose emergence in 2003 was thought to be tied to animal sales). Such events are often tied to the sale of live animals or the consumption of bushmeat. China also has extensive wildlife and livestock farming, wildlife trafficking, many live animal markets and lax regulations. Soon after a mysterious new pneumonia appeared in China, the source of the disease was quickly pinned to the animals sold in the Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan. Many (although not all) of the people who had become sick had worked at or visited this site.

Yet a “natural” spillover is not the only route by which a new virus might enter humans. Researchers at the Wuhan Institute of Virology ( WIV ) had also been carrying out high-risk research on coronaviruses in inadequate biosafety conditions. Scientists in the city also conducted field trips to sample bats and collect viruses from remote regions of China. These activities could have provided a route for a new virus to be accidentally picked up by humans in the laboratory, who could then have gone on to start an outbreak in Wuhan.

Since the start of the pandemic, two tribes have battled it out in online discussions of the origins of covid: the “zoonati” and the “lab leakers”. Michael Worobey, professor of ecology and evolutionary biology at the University of Arizona, didn't start out as a zoonati, a term that was once pejorative on social media and thrown at those who didn't support a laboratory leak. (Dr Worobey says the word has been “happily” co-opted.) He says there are three main lines of evidence that support the market hypothesis: geographic, zoonotic and evolutionary.

The strongest evidence is probably the first: the spatial pattern of the earliest cases which centred on a small animal market in a city of 11m people. Although there was some bias towards collecting cases from the market (given its early implication in the outbreak), Dr Worobey says the very earliest onset cases, ones that just turned up in hospitals, lived in a “bullseye right around the market”.

It is also clear that animals that could be infected with SARS-CoV-2 were being sold in the Huanan Seafood Market. By June 2021 this zoonotic line of evidence was firmed up in a paper published in Scientific Reports , in which swabs of the surfaces and corners of the market collected in January 2020 indicated that various species such as raccoon dogs, badgers, mink and civet cats were present before the pandemic. None of these animals were disclosed by the Chinese authorities; they were found thanks to market surveillance under way before the outbreak. The animals were sold alive, in cages stacked on top of one another, and in poor conditions. Many shops offered butchering services. And the route to the market would also have brought stressed animals into close contact, allowing for the intermingling and amplification of coronaviruses.

One note of caution here is that, although the animals found at the market were capable of hosting the human variant of SARS-CoV-2 , whether the pandemic virus emerged here is not provable with the information available. The viruses picked up by the swabs taken at the market in January 2020 could also have come from infected humans in the market, rather than from animals.

The third line of evidence for the market hypothesis comes from studying how different specimens of the virus are related to each other, from an evolutionary point of view. As coronaviruses replicate, random mutations occur in its genome and are passed on to successive generations. Over time these changes will accrue. If viruses are sampled from many different people over time, it is possible to work out which viruses begat other viruses, and the amount and rate of the changes can tell scientists roughly what the virus's evolutionary history looks like.

In 2022 Jonathan Pekar of the University of California, San Diego, and colleagues found that two major lineages of SARS-CoV-2 appeared at the start of the outbreak in Wuhan, known as A and B. These were likely, said the researchers, to be the result of at least two separate spillover events in humans. The combination of the geographic pattern of cases around the market, a short timeline for the emergence of the virus, and two independent lineages, paint a picture of a market-related event tied to a group of infected animals carrying similar (but not identical) versions of the SARS-CoV-2 virus that jumped.

Again, not everyone agrees. Other scientists have challenged the idea that the two lineages of SARS-CoV-2 represented separate introductions. As they differ by only two mutations, one lineage could have evolved into another within humans, they argue, rather than coming from separate spillover events.

The question is whether quibbles like these create enough wriggle room to leave open the possibility that the pandemic started elsewhere, leaving the market to be simply a place where the number of infections in humans was amplified. The hope was that the ODNI would resolve this issue one way or another, particularly in relation to persistent rumours that scientists at the WIV were infected with the first cases of covid-19. On this matter the report was clear—although some researchers at WIV did fall ill in the autumn of 2019, the symptoms reported were not diagnostic of covid-19. In other words, they could have been sick with any disease.

Another remaining area of uncertainty concerns missing data from the early days of the outbreak in Wuhan. Maria Van Kerkhove, an infectious disease epidemiologist at the World Health Organisation says her group has repeatedly asked for an independent re-analysis of surveillance cases in 2019 that had been ruled out as being covid-19. And also she has asked for more information about the 174 early cases of covid-19 that China has disclosed. What this obfuscation and opacity from China amounts to is unclear. However, Dr Worobey points out that there were probably only a handful of cases of covid in late November 2019, and that six retrospective studies, including on throat swabs, blood donors and plasma samples, do not find a signal of a larger outbreak in November—although they did find that influenza was relatively common at the time.

Prior to the release of the ODNI ’s report, two-thirds of Americans believed a laboratory leak was the cause of the pandemic, according to a poll by The Economist and YouGov. This impression came despite the growth of scientific papers pointing to the market. Last week's release of intelligence will not persuade people on either side that they might be wrong. Instead it will fuel a new cycle of claims and counterclaims. Yet with further new information not expected, the marginal gains of continuing the row are rapidly diminishing. The hunt for the heroes and villains of covid is drawing energy and attention from the more obviously urgent need to improve global biosecurity in the animal trade and lab safety. The mysterious origins of covid may, for now, need to take a back seat. ■

; Mon, 26 Jun 2023 16:01:32 GMT /content/mo6ekpdgv2s3p1mnoa3v1jivh8hp59ev https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/06/26/an-acrimonious-debate-about-covids-origins-will-rumble-on Why an American novel set in Russia was pulled from publication

E LIZABETH GILBERT , an American author, is more used to soul-searching than grappling with geopolitical problems. Her best-known work, “Eat, Pray, Love”, is a memoir about life after divorce. But in recent weeks she has been ruminating on a grislier subject: Russia's invasion of Ukraine. On June 12th Ms Gilbert postponed indefinitely the publication of a novel, “The Snow Forest”, after hundreds of angry posts on Goodreads, a review site, mainly from Ukrainians. They object to the fact that the novel is set in Russia, in a religious-fundamentalist community in Soviet-era Siberia. Ms Gilbert's decision had free-speech advocates fulminating over the dangers of cancel culture. Why is popular fiction being pulled into discourse about the invasion?

The furore is a curious episode in a broader debate . When the war began, many Western galleries, museums and concert halls struck Russian works from their programmes or cancelled performances by Russian artists. They were concerned that celebrating Russian culture would signal tacit acceptance of the Kremlin's aggression. In some cases, the performers in question did indeed have links to the Russian state. Valery Gergiev, for instance, a famous conductor, played a concert organised by the Kremlin in Palmyra, a Syrian city, in 2016 after Russian forces helped the Syrian army to recapture it from Islamic State. State-backed institutions such as the Bolshoi Theatre have long enjoyed a glowing international reputation.

Severing links to such individuals and organisations blocked obvious avenues for Russian soft power. But other aspects of the debate are more complicated. Some Russian artists who had publicly condemned the war also had their performances cancelled. Some people even suggested that 19th-century Russian literary greats, such as Fyodor Dostoyevsky and Alexander Pushkin, should be reappraised. Western readers, the theory went, had been blind to the imperial sentiments of these authors, who had helped to cultivate a thirst for expansionism within Russian culture and society.

These writers' works do, in places, include brazen support for imperial conquest. But associating long-dead authors with Russia's invasion is a stretch (plenty of Western authors of the time held imperialist views). Ms Gilbert's case takes the discussion to an altogether different, and frankly puzzling, level: merely writing about Russia is cast as being incompatible with showing support for Ukraine. It is unsurprising that her decision to delay the novel's publication has been called “well-intended” but “wrongheaded” by PEN America, a non-profit organisation that promotes artistic free expression.

Still, the backlash against “The Snow Forest” reflects frustration in Ukraine. From intellectuals to keyboard warriors, many Ukrainians bemoan what they perceive as a Western tendency to romanticise Russian culture as a source of universal wisdom on human nature, justice and power. They also accuse Westerners of regularly mislabelling art from other places in Eurasia, including Ukraine, as “Russian”.

Scholars in the West are taking note. Many speak of “decolonising” the study of Russia and eastern Europe. That means encouraging academics to focus on the legacy of Russian imperialism in their research and persuading universities to expand their teaching of other eastern European cultures. Studying the culture of the ethnic minorities who live within Russia is also important, notes Elena Sudakova, head of Pushkin House, an arts institute in London that focuses on work from Russia and its neighbours. It is unclear whether “The Snow Forest” would have touched on these subjects.

For Ms Gilbert, the stakes of the Goodreads debacle seem relatively low: she will probably publish her novel one day. For Ukrainians, the stakes are higher. The Kremlin denies the existence of a discrete Ukrainian history and identity. That makes culture a matter of survival. ■

; Mon, 26 Jun 2023 15:51:44 GMT /content/859t30ibq46d8d0s7k46nrc0ren7qmq0 https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2023/06/26/why-an-american-novel-set-in-russia-was-pulled-from-publication Why Reddit users are protesting against the site’s leadership

O N JUNE 12TH large parts of Reddit, a social-media platform with nearly 56m active daily users, went dark. The site is made up of forums, known as subreddits. Moderators—users who run these forums on a voluntary basis—removed 8,000 of the most popular from public view for two days. They were protesting against Reddit's plan to charge some third-party-app developers for access to the site's data. By June 14th most moderators had made their subreddits public again; on June 26th, about a third remained private.

Users are finding other novel ways to disrupt the platform: moderators designated harmless subreddits such as r/MildlyInteresting, where people share photos, as “Not Safe For Work”, indicating that posts may be pornographic, violent, or otherwise unsuitable to browse in the office. A subreddit about modern fashion is asking that users only post about 18th-century clothing. Why are Reddit's users demonstrating in this idiosyncratic way?

Reddit is the world's 8th most popular website. It was founded in 2005, and in its early years did little to police speech on the platform. As it has commercialised, Reddit has introduced new rules to limit acceptable posts, sometimes at the request of users. It has basic site-wide standards (eg, no racism), but moderators make most of the decisions about what is and is not acceptable on a forum.

These volunteers have been a boon. They have allowed Reddit's bosses to outsource tricky decisions about thelimits of free speech to users. And they have saved the site money: a paper by researchers at Northwestern University, in Illinois, and the University of Minnesota Twin Cities found that if Reddit were to pay its moderators $20 an hour, the average wage for such work in America, it would cost $3.4ma year.

But Reddit's user-controlled model is under strain. Moderators' powerful role, and the site's libertarian ethos, have made them territorial, and made Reddit particularly vulnerable to revolts whipped up by the leaders of individual forums. This year Twitter met little resistance when it started charging third-party app developers.

Reddit says it is introducing charges to stop large language models , which underpin artificial-intelligence services such as ChatGPT , from scraping its data free of charge. Such models are creating a huge amount of money for companies like OpenAI, of which Reddit gets little. But users fear that the change will harm popular third-party apps. Many consider Reddit's own app to be clunky. They prefer browsing the site on other apps with sleeker designs, such as Apollo and RIF. Christian Selig, who runs Apollo, said he would close it down on June 30th because he cannot afford to pay $20ma year to Reddit to keep operating. Moderators are particularly dependent on third-party apps, which make running subreddits easier. And users worry that a carve-out for accessibility apps, which help visually impaired users access Reddit, will not be inclusive enough.

Still, Reddit is likely to go ahead with changes. It is eager to increase its revenue ahead of an initial public offering ( IPO ) this year. According to PitchBook, a data firm, the site was worth $10bn when it last raised funds in 2021. It is unlikely to reach that valuation now: the IPO market has cooled and Reddit is not profitable. The user revolt may also have spooked investors. Steve Huffman, Reddit's boss, believes that the protests are the work of a disgruntled minority and will pass. That may be true. But its users are what give Reddit value—the site's bosses should be careful not to gamble away their goodwill. ■
